conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light, creating a region where the light source is not directly visible.
The size and shape of the shadow depend on the position of the light source, the size and shape of the object, and the distance between the object and the surface on which the shadow is cast.
The light source is at a certain height above the objects, and each object (apple, paper, plastic, and bone) casts a shadow (A, B, C, and D) on the ground.
When the light source moves upward, the angle at which light rays hit the objects changes, and the distance between the light source and the objects increases.
As the light source moves upward, the angle of the light rays becomes more perpendicular to the objects, causing shadows to generally become smaller.
The position of the shadows will shift closer to the objects because the light rays are coming from a higher angle, reducing the lateral displacement of the shadows from the objects.
Shadow A (Apple) will become smaller and move closer to the apple.
Shadow B (Paper) will become smaller and move closer to the paper.
Shadow C (Plastic) will become smaller and move closer to the plastic.
Shadow D (Bone) will become smaller and move closer to the bone.
When the light source moves upward, the shadows (A, B, C, and D) will decrease in size and move closer to the respective objects.
